summary: The appellant-Ravinder Kumar has filed an appeal against the judgment and order passed by the Division Bench of the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi on 12th October, 2015 in Criminal Appeal No.287 of 2015, thereby dismissing the appeal filed by the appellant herein. The Delhi High Court has set aside the conviction and sentence of the appellant herein and Pushpender (accused No.2) for the offence punishable under Section 304B read with Section 34 IPC while maintaining the sentence awarded by the trial court to the appellant for the offence punishable under Section 302/34 IPC. Shri Geeta Kapoor, learned counsel appearing for the prosecution, submits that the prosecution has failed to prove the guilt of the appellant under Section 302 IPC.

summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that a delay of 72 days in filing an appeal against acquittal in a criminal case cannot be grounds for condonation of delay in filing an appeal against acquittal. The Supreme Court has held that an application for special leave to appeal from an order of acquittal under sub-section 3 of Section 417 of the old CrPC would not apply to an application under the old Limitation Act. Section 5 of Limitation Act, 1963 is not applicable in the present case as it was laid down by Kaushalya Rani (supra).

summary: Appeal by Md. Rahim Ali @ Abdur Rahim vs The State Of Assam on 11 July, 2024 A writ petition has been filed in the High Court against deportation of a Pakistani man from India. Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the appellant was not declared a foreigner by the National Green Tribunal because his name was not included in the National Register of Citizens (NRC) as he was declared a foreigner way back in the year 2012 and as per the judgment of this Court in Abdul Kuddus v Union of India, Paragraph 271, 6 SCC 604, a person whose name is not included in the NRC and is declared a foreigner by the Tribunal can only move before the High Court in writ proceedings.

summary: The Indian National Security Council (INSC) has filed a petition in the Supreme Court challenging a lower court's order quashing an FIR registered against a team of soldiers accused of assaulting a soldier in Kashmir. The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Union of India and the Ministry of Defence on two writ petitions filed by the wives of officers of the Indian Army for quashing of an FIR registered against them under Sections 302, 307, 326, 201, 34 read with Section 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. On 19th July, 2022, the Supreme Court of India, in an interim order, granted time to the State of Nagaland and the Union of India, to file an affidavit and prayed for three weeks’ time to do the needful.

summary: The Jharkhand High Court has issued the following directions: The Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860) provides for the following: The procedure for investigation has been laid down in Section 157 of Cr.P.C. which states inter alia that if from the information received or otherwise, an officer in charge of a police station has reason to suspect the commission of an offence which he is empowered under Section 156 to investigate, he shall forthwith send a report of the same to a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of such offence upon a police report and shall proceed in person, or shall depute one of his subordinate officers to proceed, to the spot, to investigate the facts and circumstances of the case, and, if necessary, to take measures for the discovery and arrest of the offender.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that when goods are redeemed after payment of fine under the Customs Act, 1962, the importer is not liable to pay duty on delayed payment under the same Act. The Supreme Court of India has held that when the owner of goods exercises the option to pay fine for redemption of goods, the obligation to pay duty and other charges under Section 125 will arise only when the owner of goods exercises the option to pay fine for redemption of goods and the Department accepts it. Section 28AB of the Customs Tariff Act, 1975 (Customs Tariff Act, 1975) provides that interest under Section 28AB is payable even for proceedings under Section 125.

summary: A bench of Justice Pamidighantam Sri Narasimha and Justice Chandrachud of the Delhi High Court has issued notice to the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi on a writ petition challenging his power to nominate 10 persons to the Delhi Municipal Corporation (DMC). Shri Abhishek Manu Singhvi, Senior Advocate General, representing the Delhi Municipal Corporation (DMC), submitted that it is the duty of the Lieutenant Governor to act on the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers. summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Reserve Bank of India on a set of appeals challenging a Delhi High Court ruling that banks can charge usurious rates of interest on credit cards. The Appellants have contended that the National Commission, vide its Judgment dated 07.07.2008, has encroached into the statutory domain of the Reserve Bank of India, by holding that the rates of interest charged by banks from credit card holders, is usurious and exploitative in nature, and in contravention of the circulars issued by the Reserve Bank of India. The Supreme Court of India has issued a notice to the Reserve Bank of India on a petition challenging a decision of the National Commission for Scheduled Banks (NCSB) that interest charged by banks on credit cards is an unfair trade practice.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that judges should be promoted on the basis of seniority rather than on the basis of merit. summary: A chronology of key events: The question before the Supreme Court is whether a legislator who receives a bribe to cast a vote in a certain direction or speak about certain issues be protected by parliamentary privilege. The Supreme Court of India, in an order dated 4 March 2024, had ruled that a member of the State Legislature could not be prosecuted for giving a vote in Parliament in a particular manner, but, in the course of the judgement in PV Narasimha Rao (supra), a five-judge bench of this Court recorded prima facie reasons doubting the correctness of the decision in PV Narasimha Rao (supra) and referred the matter to a larger bench of seven judges.

summary: Chandigarh Housing Board vs Tarsem Lal on 7 February, 2024 The Punjab and Haryana High Court has dismissed an appeal filed by the Chandigarh Administration against the judgment and decree of the trial court in a suit brought by a member of the Scheduled Tribes of Chandigarh. It was submitted that the High Court was not right in interpreting a decree of the Ministry of Welfare, Government of India in the case of Marri Chandra Shekhar Rao by ignoring the fact that the caste status could be claimed insofar as the State or Union Territory of a person’s origin only and not carried to a State or Union Territory to which the person migrates.

summary: The Delhi High Court has condoned the fine of Rs.95,00,000 imposed on the former director general of the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), Ashok Sirpal, in a corruption case. Shri Arun Kumar Singh, senior counsel representing the High Court of Jharkhand, submitted that the impugned order of the High Court of Jharkhand suspending the sentence and fine of the respondent in default of payment of the fine was erroneous. The respondent has been sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for seven years and ordered to pay a fine of Rs.95,00,000/.

summary: Appeal from the High Court of Karnataka against an order of the Court of Additional Judge-III, Mangalore, allowing the petition of the respondent under Article 227 of the Constitution. A writ petition has been filed in the High Court of Karnataka against an order of the Trial Court, Bangalore, impounding a Power of Attorney (GPA) executed in favour of a third party and directing the respondent to pay a penalty of ten times the stamp duty paid. This is an appeal from the High Court's order setting aside of the Trial Court's order by which it had dismissed the appellant's civil appeal against the seizure of his property by the police.

summary: Indore Vikas Praadhikaran (Ida) vs Shri Humud Jain Samaj Trust on 25 November, 2024 The Indore Development Authority (IDA) has been held by the Indore High Court to be justified in cancelling the first National Invitation for Tender (NIT) and going for the second NIT. Learned Senior Counsel for the appellant has vehemently argued before this Court that the order passed by the Division Bench of the High Court should not be set aside as the High Court has in fact decided a suit for specific performance of contract while deciding the Writ Appeal.

summary: Appeal by Mulakala Malleshwara Rao against an order of the High Court for the State of Telangana at Hyderabad dated 22 nd December, 2022 passed in Criminal Petition No.28 of 2022 on the file of XXVIth Metropolitan, Cyberabad, under Naveen 6 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961. A case has been registered under Section 173 Cr.P.C. The Supreme Court of India in a landmark case in 1997 held: ‘ Stridhana property is not a joint property of the wife and the husband and the husband (1997) 2 SCC 397 has no title or independent dominion over the property as owner thereof. Therefore, stridhana property does not become a joint property of the wife and the husband and the husband (1997) 2 SCC 397 has no title or independent dominion over the property as owner thereof.”

summary: Appeal by Avitel Post Studioz Limited against the order dated 25.04.20 in the Arbitration Petition No. 833 of 2015 and Notice of Motion No. 2475 of 2016 whereunder, the High Court has facilitated the enforcement of the final Award dated 274 issued in the SIAC Arbitration No. HSBC Investment Holdings (Mauritius) Limited ("HSBC"), a subsidiary of HSBC Holdings plc, sued appellants, Avitel Post Studioz Limited and Avitel Mauritius Limited ("Appellants"), alleging that the appellants had defrauded HSBC out of US$ 50 million by falsely claiming that they had signed a contract with British Broadcasting Corporation ("BBC"), a UK-based corporation. summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that a woman who was allegedly sexually assaulted as a child can have a termination of her pregnancy even if she is mentally fit. The Bombay High Court has directed that a Medical Board should be constituted to examine afresh a 14-year-old girl who was allegedly sexually assaulted by her father. The High Court of Maharashtra has set aside a judgement of the Bombay High Court of Judicature at Bombay dated 4 April 2024, which directed the Dean at Sion Hospital to constitute a team of doctors for the medical termination of pregnancy of a minor who is 14 years old.

summary: The Supreme Court of India on 23 October, 2024 issued an interim order to the Union of India, States and the Union Territories to ensure that no prisoner is subjected to torture, cruel, inhumane and degrading treatment or punishment because of living in overcrowded and unhygienic conditions in jail. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who is too poor to afford a lawyer and who would, therefore, have to go through the trial without legal assistance, cannot possibly be regarded as “reasonable, fair and just”. In our series of letters from African journalists, film-maker and columnist Sharmila Tagore looks back at some of the judgements of the Supreme Court that have shaped our understanding of fundamental rights.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the state of Rajasthan has the power and jurisdiction to levy and collect stamp duty on policies of insurance issued within the state. The Rajasthan High Court has dismissed the writ appeal of Life Insurance Corporation of India against the order of the Additional Collector of Bharatpur imposing stamp duty on the company’s insurance policies. The High Court of Rajasthan has held that the state of Rajasthan does not have the legislative competence to impose and collect stamp duty on insurance policies as the same falls under the Union List.

summary: The Bombay High Court has dismissed four writ petitions filed by former employees of Air India. The writ petitions were filed on 16 May, 2024 against the Government of India and respondent No. 3(AIL), particularly in its role as an employer, did not subsist and disposed of the writ petitions vide common impugned judgment dated 20thR. The Supreme Court of India's judgment in Reliance Industries Ltd v. Union of India & Ors.12, wherein the Division Bench of Calcutta High Court, after 12 (2007) SCC OnLine Cal 264 adverting to the extant principles concerning the maintainability of writ proceedings as on the date of the institution, held that an employer which had been privatised during the pendency of a writ appeal filed against the order rejecting the writ petition would continue to be amenable to writ jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution of India.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Election Commission of India, Assam, on a writ petition filed by Karim Uddin Barbhuiya challenging an order of the Gauhati High Court dismissing his election petition. summary: The National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) has allowed a revision petition filed by the opposite party insurer-company, thereby setting aside orders passed by the District Consumer Forum and sustaining the repudiation of the complainant’s claim by the opposite party insurer-company. The National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) has held that a claim for an insurance policy taken by a person who later died could not be vitiated by fraud as no documentary evidence was available to show that the deceased-insured had taken other insurance policies from other companies. The appellant has submitted that the NCDRC was incorrect in upholding the repudiation of claim in the absence of an iota of documentary evidence on record to support the contention that the insured-deceased had suppressed any fact under Clause 6 of the Proposal Form about the previous policies issued by other insurers.

summary: Abhishek Banerjee vs Directorate of Enforcement on 9 September, 2024 The appellants were served with a Summons dated 22.07.2021 under Section 50 of Prevention of Money laundering Act (PMLA) for their personal appearance in New Delhi along with the documents/records stated in the said Summons. The appellants have moved the Supreme Court challenging the summoning of them by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) under the Prevention of Money laundering Act (PMLA) on the ground that it was "illegal and reeks mala fide".

summary: The following is a chronology of key events: The Supreme Court of India has held that the Apex Grievance Redressal Committee (AGAGRC) of the Bombay High Court was wrong to terminate the agreement between a developer and a co-operative society under the Slum Rehabilitation Act, 2003. The Slum Rehabilitation Authority of India (SRA) has the power to re-determine the agreement between the developer and the slum-dwellers if the project is not completed within the stipulated time, says the Bombay High Court in a landmark case. Case after case, the Bombay High Court has been ruling that, a) the developer is duty-bound to complete the project within the stipulated time and that b) the Slum Rehabilitation Authority (SRA) has not merely the power but a broader duty to ensure that the developer completes the project

summary: The Karnataka High Court has held that the University Grants Commission (UGC) has no power to reserve a post in a university for a candidate belonging to a scheduled tribe. The Bangalore University had appointed the appellant, who was not in the age bracket of 29-40 years, in the post of Reader, without following the rules framed under the 2001 Rules. In our series of letters from African journalists, filmmaker and columnist M Ilyas Khan looks at the Reservation Act, 1990 and how it relates to the Karnataka Civil Services (Unfilled Vacancies reserved for the persons belonging to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Special Recruitment) Rules, 2001 for filling up of vacancies reserved for persons belonging to the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

summary: The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code of India, 2016 has come into force on 26 October 2017 and has come into force on 23 July, 2024. The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has dismissed two appeals against an order of the adjudicating authority of the Bombay High Court, which held that a resolution plan submitted by the appellant in respect of the 2nd respondent-corporate debtor was not in consonance with the provisions of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code of India (IBC). The learned counsel appearing for the 2nd respondent-corporate debtor has submitted that the assets allegedly part of the CIRP of ACIL, which is the holding company of the 2nd respondent-corporate debtor, cannot be included in the scope of the resolution process.

summary: A bench of the Supreme Court of India has granted leave to Srikant Upadhyay to appeal against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dismissing his application for anticipatory bail. In a landmark case, the Patna High Court has ruled that an accused against whom a non-bailable warrant is pending and the process of proclamation under Section 82, Cr.PC is issued, is not entitled to the relief of anticipatory bail. We are of the view that the application for pre-arrest bail, proclamation under Section 82, Cr.PC, should not have been issued and at any rate, its issuance shall not be a reason for declining to consider such application on merits.

summary: The State Of Uttar Pradesh vs Virendra Bahadur Katheria on 15 July, 2024 Author: Surya Kant Bench: Surya Kant 2024 The pay scales for the posts of Deputy Basic Shiksha Adhikari (Rupees), Deputy Basic Shiksha Adhikari (Rupees) and Headmasters in the State of Uttar Pradesh have been the same since 1945, with effect from 01.07.2001. This case relates to a writ petition filed by the Sri Lanka School Headmasters’ Association (SDHA) against the State on the ground that the pay scales of the Assistant Basic Education Officer (ABO) and the District Inspector of Schools (DIS) were not equal to those of the Assistant Basic Education Officer (ABO) and the District Inspector of Schools (DIS).

summary: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) has filed an appeal in the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir against the judgement of the Division Bench of the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir at Jammu in Criminal Appeal (D) No.11/2020 dated 27.04.2021 by which the judgment rendered by the Special Judge, National Investigation Agency (NIA) (3 rd Additional Sessions Judge) was confirmed in part, while remitting the issue pertaining to the charges framed under Sections 306 and 411 of the Jammu and Kashmir State Ranbir Penal Code SVT. The appellant, Owais Amin, has challenged the decision of the Special Judge, NIA, to take cognizance for the offences punishable under Sections 121, 121-A and 122 RPC, 1989, along with Sections 306 and 411 of RPC, 1989 and Section 39 of UAPA, 1967. Section 196 of the Indian Penal Code (CrPC) was introduced in 1989 to deal with the offences committed against the State.

summary: Appeal by Thakore Umedsing Nathusing and others against the conviction and sentence passed by the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad for rioting during the Gujarat riots in 2002. On the complaint of Kanji Chhara, the Banaskantha Police received a tip-off that a jeep taxi had been hired by him from a man named Bharatbhai and thereafter he was murdered and his body was burnt in a forest near Banaskantha. Two separate chargesheets came to be filed against the accused in the Court of Judicial Magistrate I st Class (JMFC) concerned for the offences punishable under Sections 302 read with Section 34 and Sections 396 and 397 of the IPC. The appellants have challenged the acquittal of them by the Gujarat High Court on the ground that the prosecution failed to prove any evidence beyond reasonable doubt.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of the Central Bureau of Investigation against the judgment of Punjab and Haryana High Court allowing the criminal appeal filed by the accused under the Prevention of Corruption Act, 19882. Section 19 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) provides as follows: “A court of appeal, on the ground of absence, error, omission or irregularity in a finding, sentence or order by a Special Judge, shall have regard to the fact whether the objection could and should have been raised at any earlier stage in the proceedings.” The High Court of Bihar has lost sight of the clear statutory prescription of Section 19 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, as informed by relevant court precedents, which provides that a sentence or an order passed by the court of competent jurisdiction shall not be reversed or altered by a court of appeal, confirmation or revision on account of any error or irregularity in any sanction for the prosecution unless in the opinion of the court, a failure of justice has in fact been occasioned thereby.

summary: The High Court of Punjab and Haryana has granted special leave to appellant Gurmeet Kaur and another appellant Kanoon Kanoon to appeal against an order of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana which had dismissed their plea to quash a criminal complaint filed against them by Devender Gupta. A writ petition was filed before the Punjab and Haryana High Court by the appellant Devender Gupta against the summoning order of the trial court and the complaint filed by him against the appellant under the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 (CrPC). The appellant Sri Aseem Mehrotra has moved the Supreme Court challenging the initiation of criminal proceedings against him under Section 197 of the CrPC by way of a private complaint.
